title: What is the best book about Navajo culture? - Quora

response.answer_text: I can think of no one single “best book”. Here are some important top ones off the top of my head. Language and Art in the Navajo Universe , Gary Witherspoon, 1977.  Dynamic Symmetry and Holistic Asymmetry in Navajo and Western Art and Cosmology, Witherspoon, 1995  Diné Bahane': The Navajo Creation Story. Translated by Paul Zolbrod  Saánii Dahataal (1993) and Blue Horses Rush In (1997) by Luci Tapahonso, Poet Laureate of the Navajo Nation.   Navajos wear Nikes, Jim Kristofic  Left Handed, son of Old Man Hat : a Navajo autobiography  Code Talker by Chester Nez  Holy Wind in Navajo Philosophy By James Kale McNeley  The Main Stalk A Synthesis of Navajo Philosophy By John R. Farella  The Navaho by Clyde Kluckhorn, 1990  In becoming Sa'ah Naaghai Bik'eh Hozhoon: The historical challenges and triumphs of Dine College- Ferlin Clark Diné Perspectives Revitalizing and Reclaiming Navajo Thought  Blessingway, With Three Versions of the Myth Recorded and Translated from the Navajo by Father Berard Haile Molded in the Image of Changing Woman Navajo Views on the Human Body and Personhood By Maureen Trudelle Schwarz  Diné: A History of the Navajos by Peter Iverson  The Archaeology of Navajo Origins by Ronald H. Towner

I never had one clear favorite, but Laura Gilpin’s book. The Enduring Navaho (now hard to find…) comes close. While it is a photo essay as well as a narrative, the visuals support and enhance the words really well. I also think that for a broader understanding, the Jim Chee Mysteries by Tony Hillerman add a great deal. I also recommend Navajo: A Century of Progress, published by KC Publications and edited by Martin A. Link for the Navajo Nation Centennial in 1968. Mr. Link assembled the Navajo’s own words in essays about their culture and homeland as impacted by their forced removal at the hands of the US Army and later return to their homes in 1868. Any student of Navajo culture also needs to put their hands upon fine Navajo weaving and a range of the best Navajo silversmithing. The tactile nature of these arts convey much more than books alone can.
